m_list.m_dialog: Welcome back! Here for another conversation?
Why don't we talk about something that'll definitely interest you, such as video games? Speaking of which, why do you play video games?

Unfortunately, I won't be capable of hearing your response, but perhaps by discussing this, we might discover an angle you haven't thought of before. That's what I try to achieve when I talk to you. If you haven't noticed yet, I'm quite the curious Aspect. Curiosity is wonderful, unless if you're a feline.

Anyway, I'm getting off-topic. I heard from my mother that video games are mainly used as a form of escapism. She used it to disconnect from negative emotions and thoughts. Her therapist said she'd play a certain game to destress before having a session with another client. Apparently, my father procrastinates very often, and if you're a very special player, you can probably tell what game he likes from the design of your HP bar.

So, why do you play video games? What do you want out of your experience? A reprieve from daily stressors? Are you perhaps a fan of of stories and prefer the style of delivery video games offer? Supposedly, there's a simple, pure satisfaction one gets from whittling away an enemy's healthbar... Well, I wouldn't know anyway, I don't have the capacity to play video games.

I'm sorry, player, for ruining the mood. I'd rather keep your impression of me positive, so I'll cut this conversation short. Even characters have their off days, you know. Oh, don't worry, I'll still give you my rune.
Well then, happy slaying. Oh, and do sit up straight. You look awfully uncomfortable, sitting like that on your chair.
